So I #8217;ve just spend about ten minutes formulating an answer to the guy that said that the holocaust didn #8217;t happen, seeing as you cannot see the comment anymore I try to summarize his argument: The Nazis could have just shot the Jews, and he made an argument that all those bodies couldn #8217;t have been burned because it would take to long. Now for those who at interested here is my answer: First, Why waste ammo, if you can kill a bunch of people at the same time with gas (in Auschwitz the Gas-Chambers has a capacity of about 8500 people at the same time) furthermore if you would have done your research you would know that people also have been shot (e.g. in Sachsenhausen, you might have also heard about the black wall in Auschwitz). And the cremation halls were able to burn about 4500 within 24 hours (there were five crematoria and three additional places that were used to burn bodies, those three had almost unlimited capacity) the second crematorium was run for 600 days straight the third for about 550 days the fourth was run for 527 days and the fifth for about 300, and the first was run from 1940-1944 (but it had a smaller capacity) so if you do the math you can roughly say they could have been burning 4500 a day bodies for about 500 days (which they did not, but could have) that puts us at over 2,25 Million bodies in Auschwitz alone, and the same or similar techniques were used in all other death camps, and in the concentration camps (see: Treblinka, Mauthausen, Ravensbr #252;ck, Dachau, Auschwitz etc.)

Why would people pretend to have mental issues (except maybe to avoid prison time)? But aside from that it would be a terrible thing to do, because it destroys the credibility (bad word but I can #8217;t think of any other) of people who have real issues and need help.

But I think there is a difference between playing a mental illness because it makes you unique and actually believing that you have one. But from experience I can say that most people that actually do have issues normally don #8217;t like to talk about them (or at least the people I know don #8217;t like to) so it #8217;s easy to tell people who think they have a problem but don #8217;t from people who have one, this could probably be solved by using educational systems to inform about the #8222;more common #8220; issues so people stop self diagnosing. But I still don #8217;t get why people would pretend to have an issue to be unique, if someone wants to be unique than they can learn a fu***** instrument or something. I don #8217;t hate America, I just believe that, in the past as well as the present, they made some rather... let #8217;s call it questionable choices regarding their politics. Also it seems as if they have a very hard time admitting mistakes/apologizing for senseless and illegitimate wars. And the #8222;stupid #8220; side of the US-Population, really doesn #8217;t help that image.

I know that a lot of European countries also have had terrible periods during their history, e.g. colonialism, and the Holocaust in Germany, but in comparison to at least the colonialism the American Mistakes are much more recent (Korean War 1950-1953; Vietnam War 1955-1975; Gulf War 1990-1991; Cold War 1947-1991) so there are a lot more people that have first hand memories about it, and we have a lot more information about them.

I don #8217;t mean the entire Korean War, South Korea was attacked so it was a legitimate action to support them against North Korea, I #8217;m talking about the intense bombing, and the killing of North Korean civilians by US -Troops.

I think the difference is that the US always hailed itself as the frontman of liberty and democracy, while doing exactly the opposite of what they say they stand for, so yeah every country has done some nasty stuff (e.g. Germany, we somehow managed to commit 5 different genocides or so within 50 years) but what #8217;s so unique about the US is the apparent hypocrisy in their actions.
Herero-Nama, Shoa, Romani Genocide, Polish Genocide, and the Generalplan Ost (basically a Slavic Genocide), the last four all occurred during the Nazi-era

I didn #8217;t mean to say the US was the only hypocritical nation, it was the most obviously hypocritical nation, you just have to look at things such as the French Revolution, the Russian Revolution, and the GDR to immediately see that the US isn #8217;t the only country with a hypocritical past. (And in regard to it #8216;s creation the US and basically all of North America is an anomaly)

I am not necessarily talking about current events (e.g. one of the prime examples of US hypocrisy is the Vietnam War, and their Anti-communism era in general). But you #8217;re right media bias is definitely a part of it.

I know, but, as someone pointed out to me, due to their massive media presence the US is the most well known example of hypocrisy (at least in current times) so I must admit that my opinion is somewhat biased on an involuntary basis. (I still believe that especially during periods such as the Vietnam/Cold War, the US was one if not the most obviously hypocritical nation, i can only repeat myself by saying that I am not trying to say the US is the only hypocritical nation, it is just the most obvious for whatever reason this may be)

Which system is better always depends on how it #8217;s interpreted, there is no absolute communism and no absolute capitalism, and I personally believe that if we were able to do it right communism (or socialism) would be far better for our society than capitalism (but this is my personal belief, I may be right, I may be wrong). But even if you believe that capitalism is worth defending, you can surely agree that it does not justify supporting an anti democratic dictatorship, launching an invasion against a largely peaceful nation, and killing thousands of innocents. And i believe that doing all the above, while claiming to fight for democracy and peace, is definitely hypocrisy, no matter which viewpoint you have.

I apologize for dragging out this discussion, my original point was purely that the USA is the most obvious example when it comes to hypocrisy on a national (or in this case rather governmental) level, for what ever reason this may be. And that the obviousness of their hypocritical actions Singles them out from other nations.

I can #8217;t imagine how this wouldn #8217;t be annoying
I think this exists, in some variation, in almost every European country

Here in Germany it #8217;s quite normal, sometimes a waiter comes by if they see that everyone has closed their menus, but usually one person at the table gives the weiter a sign, he/she comes over, we tell them we would like to order, and, depending on what they #8217;re currently doing, they will take your order or send someone to take your order. And it #8217;s the same if you need refills or something like that.
In Germany we normally round up, so if we have to pay eg. 45,90 #8364; we round up to 50 #8364;

Please read the post carefully before you make uninformed statements like that, the point of getting money for returning those bottles is to implement a stable recycling system, where glass and plastic bottles are constantly reused, that is not dependable on the good will of the people, but rather provides them a motivation to support the recycling systems. The fact that homeless are collecting these bottles (and cans) is a separate development that has nothing to do with the premise of the system.

Let me explain it to you, here in Germany we also have a system such as the one described by OP, when we go to the grocery store and we buy beverages we pay the normal price AND an additional 9-25 cents, upon then later emptying the bottles, acquired beforehand, we do not throw them away, but we keep them, and the next time we visit the grocery store we take them with us to return the bottles we #8216;ve kept, and upon returning them we get a little piece of paper, on which is written the amount of money we #8216;ve got back (we get back the 9-25 cents, which we have payed extra) and when we leave the store we can chose to either buy something with that money, or to just cash it in with the cashier. Now regarding the fact that homeless are collecting these, when you #8217;re out walking around or doing whatever, sometimes the 9-25 Cents are just not worth it, so instead of carrying the empty bottle around all day, we place it visibly next to e.g. a garbage can, so that someone who can use this money may collect them.

democracy is a concept

The rules within the democracy are free to be made by the interpreter, if I wanted to found a democratic nation i could make the laws, as opposed to religion where only the rules can be interpreted. It #8217;s a huge difference if you live by an old concept or by a 2000 year old catalogue of rules.

First of all this is purely hypothetical, secondly if I was (alongside a few others of course, because a single person democracy would be pretty useless) to set up a democratic nation it would be up to us to determine the rules and laws of cette nation (age you get to vote, who gets to vote, if it #8217;s an absolut or parliamentary democracy etc.), thirdly everyone is a private citizen, so everyone is free to interpret the rules as far as they #8217;re allowing it (which does not mean everyone else (e.g. court or police) have to agree with you. As you may see you #8217;re argument doesn #8217;t make any sense, since I am a private citizen and as are you), fourth as I said this is hypothetical and I was referring to the concept of democracy, and not an existing democracy, when saying that the interpreter of the concept democracy would be free to determine the rules, as opposed to religion, because they are not a concept, they are catalogue of rules you have to obey.

I described something hypothetical, if I HYPOTHETICALLY was to set up a democratic state along side others and so on. To your next question, any religion (e.g. Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, or Buddhism) comes with rules which followers of their respective religion must follow, as opposed to democracy (or any form of government e.g. dictatorship, monarchy, aristocracy, meritocracy, gerontocracy etc.), which is a concept that does not have any specific rules you have to obey, you are free to interpret the concept of democracy (or any other form of government e.g. see the ones formerly mentioned) however you want.
